Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Dynamics in the Mesosphere and Lower Thermosphere over the Andes Lidar Observatory
Award.AbstractNarration:
This is a 5-year scientific collaboration to investigate the dynamics in the mesosphere and lower thermosphere (MLT) over the Andes Mountains in northern Chile. The objective is to characterize and understand wave phenomenology in the 80 to 100 km region, including background state interactions and effects. The investigation will be carried out at the newly established Andes Lidar Observatory (ALO) at Cerro Pachón (30.3°S, 70.7°W, 2530 m), Chile. This location is uniquely important for wave studies because it is a region of steep terrain and prolific wave generation that produces particularly pure examples of terrain generated waves due to the extreme dryness of the area and relative lack of convection, and it provides data for a region, the subtropical Southern Hemisphere, that currently is poorly characterized in terms of planetary waves, tides and gravity waves. The suite of instruments at ALO comprises a Na wind/temperature lidar, an all sky imager, a multichannel photometer, a mesospheric temperature mapper, an infrared camera, and a meteor radar, which will be used to observe waves and wave phenomena over a wide range of spatial and temporal scales. The project aims to provide the most detailed study to date from a Southern Hemisphere mountainous site of the characteristics and variability of instabilities, gravity waves, tides, planetary waves and mean winds and their interactions over a continuous 5-year period. Specific questions that will be addressed include:
1) What is the climatology of waves and wave related phenomenology over the Andes?
2) What are the origins, lifecycle and morphology of instabilities at ALO?
3) What atmospheric conditions lead to the formation of various wave phenomena?
4) What are the characteristics of the interactions between tides, planetary waves and gravity waves and their effects on the MLT variability?

The project will provide new education and training opportunities for students at all three universities involved. International collaborations with strong student involvement will also be pursued under this project with the Ciudad Universitaria, Argentina and the University of Adelaide, Australia. The unique dataset collected during this project will be made available to the scientific community and will support research on a wide range of scientific topics in both atmospheric science and astronomy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant supported the University of Illinois meteor radar as one component of a collaborative multi-instrument investigation of dynamics in the mesophere and lower thermosphere over the Andes mountains in northern Chile. The meteor radar was used to measure atmospheric winds at altitudes of 80-100 km. The suite of instruments located at the site includes the UIUC meteor radar, UIUC Multichannel Photometer, Utah State Mesopheric Temperature Mapper, UIUC Na Lidar, and Aerospace Nightglow Imager. These instruments are housed in the Andes Lidar Observatory (ALO) facility located near the top of Cerro Pachon, Chile (30.3S, 70.7W, 2530m elevation). 

Two journal publications summarize results obtained from multi-instrument studies of small-scale instabilities in the mesosphere above Cerro Pachon. In one paper, meteor radar data provided the background-wind context for very high spatial/temporal resolution observations of the breakdown of a mountain-wave into small-scale turbulence. Because mountain waves are nearly stationary, the breakdown process was observed over several hours; a much longer interval than has previously been observed for any such wave breakdown. Our results provided quantitative data that should help to improve the parameterization of small-scale turbulence in numerical models of the atmosphere. 

In another publication joint observations from the ALO instruments were used to study the evolution of an atmospheric instability. Observations were compared with earlier observations from the same instruments at Hawaii, with theory, and with Direct Numerical Simulations (DNS). These observations provide a detailed picture of how secondary instabilities form after the initiation of a primary, large-scale, Kelvin Helmholtz instability. 

 Another publication summarizes a study of simultaneous measurements of the quasi 2-day wave oscillation in mesospheric winds at Adelaide, Australia and at ALO in Chile. We found remarkable consistency between the 2-day-wave oscillations at these two sites. The oscillations are nearly in phase in terms of local time at the two sites, consistent with a global-scale wave-number 3 2-day normal mode. Data from several years show that the amplitude of the diurnal (24 hour) tide decreases when the 2-day wave is largest. These observations support the hypothesis that the phase-locked 2-day-oscillation is a so-called "subharmonic parametric instability" wherein the diurnal tide transfers energy to a 2-day oscillation that is resonant at nearly 48 h.

With respect to insfrastructure at the ALO facility --- initially, the meteor radar was located separate from the ALO building, at the base of the mountain that houses the ALO facility, at the entrance gate to the road leading up to the top of the mountain. This location was chosen instead of the ALO facility because there was concern that the radar transmitter might cause interference to ongoing and future astronomical observations on Cerro Pachon. It turned out that the network connection at the radar's original location was not reliable enough to enable remote control of the radar system. In addition, poor environmental control resulted in damage to the radar electronics. We addressed this issue during the last year of our activities, when we moved the meteor radar system up to the top of the mountain, to the Andes Lidar Observatory building.

With the move to the top of the mountain, it is necessary to demonstrate to the astronomy community that future meteor radar operations will not cause electromagnetic interference to their activities. To date, on the basis of some limited test transmissions, no interference has been reported by the astronomers. We anticipate that the radar system will be able to operate 24/7 (under future NSF support) in its current location at the top of Cerro Pachón once the remaining issues with the electronic hardware have been addressed.
